newsitem.title: USA: Advanced Gravis deal raises opposition.
newsitem.headline: Advanced Gravis deal raises opposition.

text.p: A group of Advanced Gravis Computer Technology Ltd shareholders said on Friday it opposed a tender offer by a unit of American Brands Inc for the maker of computer game technology.
On August 16, Advanced Gravis said it agreed to an offer from American Brands' ACCO World Corp to buy all Advanced Gravis shares for C$0.45 each.

Norm Levenson, a spokesman for a dissident group claiming to hold a minimum of two million Gravis shares, said Friday his group was seeking an order from U.S. and Canadian securities regulators to halt the deal.
The company, which trades on the Toronto stock exchange and as a bulletin board stock in the United States, has 19 million shares outstanding.
The stock was trading at C$0.41 per share on the Toronto Exchange early Friday afternoon.
In a statement, the dissident group accused company executives and directors of ignoring shareholder interests.
The company maintains that the group represents only a minority of shareholders.
"Individually, they don't own enough shares to be able to change things," said company spokeswoman Merilee Rush.
Advanced Gravis manufactures controls used in popular "twich-action" video games. The company had revenues of C$10.6 million in the first quarter of fiscal 1997 ended in April.
